title: graph theory - Subgraph induced by negative cycles detected by Bellman-Ford algorithm
body: What is known about the properties of the subgraph induced by the negative cycles are defined by the predecessor relation that is established during the execution of the Bellman-Ford algorithm and arcs $(u,v)$ satisfying $\mathrm{dist}(u)+\omega(u,v)\lt\mathrm{dist}(v)$ after its execution? Assuming that the negative cycles are vertex-disjoint, is it true that re-running the Bellman-Ford algorithm after the weights of negative-cycle arcs have been multiplied by $-1$ , no negative cycles will be found in that 2nd execution? graph-theory algorithms Share Cite Improve this question Follow asked Jul 23, 2020 at 12:52 Manfred Weis 14k 4 4 gold badges 40 40 silver badges 82 82 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 4 $\begingroup$ Manfred, I do not quite understand how the multiplication by -1 comes in? Why does this multiplication take place? $\endgroup$ Mary Sp. –  Mary Sp. 2020-07-24 15:23:43 +00:00 Commented Jul 24, 2020 at 15:23 $\begingroup$ @MaryS. it is because the negative edges resemble edges in the non-optimal matching $M$, whose direction has been inverted and their weight multiplied by $-1$. After having detected a negative cycle, we exchange edges in $M$ corresponding to the negative edges on that cycle with the positive ones on that cycle, reducing $|M|$. For the next iteration we must undo the inversion of direction and negation of weights for edges removed from $M$ and do it for the added ones and, and the reason for multiplying with $-1$ is that do ing it twice amounts to undo ing it. $\endgroup$ Manfred Weis –  Manfred Weis 2020-07-25 07:47:48 +00:00 Commented Jul 25, 2020 at 7:47 $\begingroup$ Let me think about it! When you say "the negative edges resemble edges in the non-optimal matching": what does the word "resemble" mean here? $\endgroup$ Mary Sp. –  Mary Sp. 2020-07-26 14:57:11 +00:00 Commented Jul 26, 2020 at 14:57 $\begingroup$ I should have said negative arcs, because the shortest path problem instance that is generated from the original graph and a matching, consists of directed arcs , whereas the edges in the original graph are undirected. $\endgroup$ Manfred Weis –  Manfred Weis 2020-07-26 15:18:57 +00:00 Commented Jul 26, 2020 at 15:18 Add a comment  |  0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
